reviewText:
The first gamebook by Tin Man Games on mobile previously, and certainly my favourite among the franchise, A nice plot-twist saves the plot from being a run-of-the-mill variety.

The story flow is good, and choices in the book made sense (eg. if you don't know where to find someone it's game over). It might be annoying to some people to have managed to make it so far into the story, only to get a gameover because they didn't have x item or y information, but it feels realistic and adds to replayability (especially since gamebooks from this company have more than one path to choose from when travelling from one point of the story to another).
Also, just note that most, if not all of the gamebooks from this company has an encounter early in the story that can make or break the game (gameover) far into the story.

There are beautiful, well-drawn illustrations scattered in the book relevant to the story passage at the time they appear. Music is pretty pleasant and didn't break immersion when reading the text.

I like how the achievements are mostly there to hint to you that there are still parts of the story you haven't seen or experienced, rather than just placed there for overachievers.

Give it a try if you're a fan of gamebooks and a good story, try to give this game a try.
Can't wait to play the sequel. :)

reviewText:
The first Story Book advanture game I have ever played on steam.

This is the first game release of Tin-man and it's a good one..

Being a DND and visual novel vetern..
I took out my trusty paper and pen start to map the story route from the beginning.

Wonderfully engaging story line with Grand twist.. (Kari..)
Decent visual with no animation...
Simple, Basic, Dice Rolling luck with Correct decision making is all you need to win this game.
It took me 10 hours to map all the routes.. With my trusty lucky dice I was able to get 100% for this game.

This game is not for everyone..
It's not for young kids that have no patience of simple story reading and dice rolling.
It's not for action lover and people like hands on engaging gameplay.
It doesn't have super good graphics and top-notch animation like some of today's game.

It's a simple and yet very elegent story book advanture!

If you like reading a book for a few hour and test your luck.. This game is for you!
8/10 would be my final rating but please.. if you don't like basic story book and dice avoid this one.

I will play the longer version of part two curse of assasin in a few days.

One more edit to this... The achievments was broken before but it's now completly fixxed.

reviewText: Assassin in Orlandes is the first of Tin Man Games's Gamebook Adventure series and what a strong start it is. A CYOA book, with dice throwing and if you wish to turn left
date: turn to page 15" blah blah style adventuring. It is a lost art
recommended: partly because many of those old Fighting Fantasy books were more or less lifeless
hoursPlayed: dripping in theme but completely lacking in storytelling skill. This story is quite a fun ride though. You start out alone in a bar
voteText: your girlfriend has left you
helpfulPercent: and before long you are swept up in a maelstrom of kidnapping
votesTotal: and even assassination! (Wait... "An Assassin in Orlandes!" I just noticed that! They must have planned that ALL ALONG! Brilliant!) Along the way
column20: and even an assassin or two. The story is not long to finish
column21: though you will want to go back and enjoy some of the branching paths
column23: the story does a wonderful job of telling a rip-roaring swashbuckling tale of adventure. The decisions are generally written with reasonable benefits and consequences if you think them through
column25: so unlike most CYOAs the game feels like it is actually a game rather than a series of choices you must iterate though. I highly recommend it for anyone who wants a CYOA story a little bit lighter on the anime VN style nonsense and heavier on swords and sorcery."

reviewText:
ENGLISH:
A Gamebook with a very interesting and engaging storyline. There are also various fonts, many black-and-white pics, plus it’s a multi-language game. On its release, there was an issue with the achievements, they would not unlock, but it had been solved.

FRENCH (FRANÇAIS):
Un livre dont VOUS êtes le Héros, ayant un scénario intéressant et étant disponible en français. Il contient aussi des choix des polices pour le texte ainsi que plusieurs illustrations en noir et blanc. Lors de sa sortie, un bogue empêchait d’obtenir les succès, mais il est maintenant résolu.

reviewText:
A choose-your-own adventure with dice.
~2 hours of story, more if you explore every story branch. Steam achievements are currently not working.

It's a book, but it's not. That can be positive (sound effects and music) and negative because you have to roll the dice to progress and you can't just leaf through it afterwards. Storywise, you're on a typical RPG adventure, you'll roll for combat and fitness checks every corner and die a lot. Which means you start over, maybe try a new path which still leads you through similar choke points until you die again. I did this 3 times on three different days because when the game makes you stop reading a story because of a virtual dice role that is frustrating, and then I switched the game from classic" mode to "casual"
date: which means it now works more the way I want it: I can just bypass the fights and checks and read on as if I'd won. And then I skip through half of the story which I've already seen in previous attempts (except the game can't skip like some Visual Novels do
recommended: you have to leaf through it and dice through it page by page) and get the rest of the humdrum fantasy campaign: betrayal
voteText: nefarious doings that our hero thwarts
helpfulPercent: but not really anything in the way of character development or in fact anything that would make me think or feel.\n\nHigh point of the writing was the time I died from a piece of timber that was floating towards me while swimming in the river. True
votesTotal: with sharp bits and nails poking out
votesFunny: but still it must've been really determined
commentsCount: or the water was just flowing much faster for that piece of wood than it was for me.\n\nSo
column16: I don't exactly recommend this; I've seen free visual novels that were better than this. If you do play this
column17: choose "Casual Mode" when you start out; contrary to what the instructions say
column18: it plays exactly like classic mode except you get more bookmarks and some "cheat" buttons - you could resolve not to use them (and only use 3 bookmarks max) and see if you make it
column19: and if you don't you won't have to start over."

reviewText: Taking from such books as Fighting Fantasy, the book follows the old style gamebooks from the 80s well written and good story should draw anyone willing to read. Good background music, and artwork, and ajustable fonts and extras. The rules are fair and the options off choices on the page is actually better then Fighting fantasy giving you more logical responses then the standard go left and right. Fighting is fluid, my main complaint is that hardcore rules only allow 3 bookmarks which isn't a problem if you plan to play the whole game in one go, there is a casual mode and you don't really have to cheat if you don't want to but still, would liked to have had a hardcore option with unlimited bookmarks. It doesn't really stop you from playing the game hardcore, I think it just prevents you from going back over and over.\n\nAll and all its a good read and you should get the game if you don't mind reading and remembering how to use your mind to picture events, its a interactive novel, that plays like a game, so even though you are reading it as a book, you still feel like it's you living the story.

reviewText: This is a straightforward digital adaptation of an old choose your own adventure book. If you're nostalgic about that style of book, you'll get a couple hours of enjoyment from this game. The problem is that, outside of nostalgia, the choose your own adventure books haven't aged very well.\n\nIf you don't know the genre already, you read a few paragraphs of text, then you either make a decision, you roll a fitness test
date: or you fight something. If you hear decisions" and start expecting Telltale Games style moral choices you're going to be disappointed. Most decisions can be summarized as "you're running down a hallway
recommended: do you turn left or right?" That could still be interesting in a puzzle-y way
hoursPlayed: but there's typically no reason to prefer one direction over another. The fitness tests and combat can be summarized as "you roll some dice
voteText: and then you either succeed or you die." There is no meaningful strategy on the combat and if you fail you just die and have to redo the combat until you succeed or switch to "casual" mode and skip over it.\n\nThese types of gamebooks were fun back in the day
helpfulPercent: and I enjoy them in a nostalgiac way; but there's no reason to play this other than nostalgia. If you want a fantasy game
votesHelpful: I'd reccomend you look up the old D&D games on GOG.com instead.\n\nEDIT: Almost forgot. The other reviews mention it
votesTotal: but I'll repeat it. The achievements are broken for a lot of people
column16: said when they'll be fixed. If that's important to you

reviewText:
This game is a story book with rolling the dice when you fight the enemies and doing fitness related task such as escaping.For fighting,there are two phrase which are attack and defense,each fight start with you attacking first then defend.The rule is that you get to roll some dice that are recording to your stat such as attack and defense.
Let say I have 2 attack and 1 defense I got to roll 2 dice when my character is on attack turn and 1 die on defense turn
the game mechanic count our dice and compared it to the opponent dice.the dice is arranged and compared by highest valued dice to the least valued dice (6 to 1).They compared each dice one by one
,For example I got 6,4,2 and my enemy got 6,5 then my enemy win that turn if you're attacking ,he doged or if he attacking ,you will take a damage depend on the sum of the dice which are 11.You can also choose to use healing item when you collect along the way.I also have fitness stat to roll the die whether I am going to get a bonus 1 to my highest die or not.
For the fitness related task, it's like you roll for the reqired fitness stat that are required to complete that task.
Tip:1)Try clicking your mouse when you roll the dice then kicking the table to make the dice roll the way you want.
2)You can try to exit the game when you lose the fight to restart the fight(Not recommend for the immersiveness)

This game is okay in the term of the storyline,it give the feel of something epic but kinda linear when explore its option.I recommend playing it on classic mode because it give you more fun and excitement hoping that you will get the good roll on the dice.It would be nice to for the publisher to fix the achivement on steam though

reviewText: I love me a good choose-your-own-adventure, and the Assassin series is a solid option for those looking for a lot of charming little split paths. Orlandes in particular I feel is a better put together tale, and although the choices you make have less impact, it's a fairly well written story. Just keep in mind that this is a two part series, so to get the full charm and see the series miniature example of developer evolution, this isn't a bad place to start. The story follows your share of tropes and leads us off on a very gentle cliffhanger. The use of old school dice to determine encounters and sneak detection is a nice touch, and going on the highest difficulty will garuntee some roadbumps along the way and some surprising challenge for a choose your own adventure story, which definitely extends it out a bit.\n\nThe story is fairly standard, all being said, but what is important is that it's an enjoyable little journey. Is it worth the 10 dollar asking price? That's...tough. Even with all the branching paths, Orlandes is a short novella at best. The sequel, which has the same asking price, has a ton more content. On sale? Definitely worth the buy, but the price tag as of now is hefty. Orlandes is one to keep an eye on, and it will probably elicit that nostalgic feeling, even if it doesn't quite capture the charm of its predecessors.

reviewText:
It's been decades since I last opened up a Choose Your Own Adventure" book;
An Assassin in Orlandes brought me back to those good ol' days :).

I enjoyed my time reading it and playing out the events in my imagination.
The story seems linear
date: and I'm not sure if there are multiple (successful) endings
recommended: but it seems there are various items along the way you can pick up (including diseases) that can affect the outcome.\n\nI'm tempted to replay it again to check out the paths I didn't explore
hoursPlayed:
but I think I'll just go on to the next game.

Can't wait to check out the sequel.

PS:  Protip: You can always tilt the machine ;)"
